Description: Small polished red pottery bowl of Nile silt clay, with flat bottom, flaring sides and everted rim, coated with red slip, burnished, and decorated on the interior in yellow-white paint with a radial design of stepped, hatched rectangles. At the rim the space between the rectangles is filled with dots, and a dot-filled circle occupies the tondo.
Curator's comments: The design may imitate basketry. White cross-line ware, Brunton Corpus C50s Discussed in: G. Graff, Les peintures sur vases de Naqada I–Naqada II: Nouvelle approche sémiologique de l’iconographie prédynastique, Leuven (2009), cat. no. 66 A. Scharff, JEA 14(1928), 261-2, pl. xxv.1
Bibliographic references: Brunton & Caton-Thompson 1928 / The Badarian Civilisation and Predynastic Remains near Badari (pl. 38.50s) (not to scale)
Acquisition name: Donated by: British School of Archaeology, Egypt
